metadata.title: An efficient 2-(2-Pyridyl)imidazole based copper catalyst for N-Arylation of N-heterocycles

(b) Spin density plot of 1 in ground state. (c) Cyclic voltammograms of 1, 2 and a mixture of 1 and 2 in DMSO/0.1 M Bu4NPF6 at 298 K vs Ag/AgCl. (d) HOMO and LUMO of 1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 On heating the mixture of 1, KOH and DMSO leads to diamagnetic EPR signal (a), shifting of paramagnetic to diamagnetic NMR signals (b) and vanishing of d-d transition (c). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Relative free energy (kcal/mol) profile diagram for the 1 catalysed N-arylation reaction obtained from B3LYP level of theory with the LANL2DZ basis set for all atoms. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Fig. 6 Scheme 1 General copper catalyzed Ullmann‒Goldberg-type (a) and Chan‒Lam-type (b) N-arylation reaction. Table 2 1-catalysed N-arylation of different N-heterocycles. a , b Table 2 Image, table 2 Image, table 2 a Reaction condition: N-heterocycles (1.0 mmol), Aryl-halides (1.5 mmol), KOH (1.5 mmol) complex 1 (5 mol%), DMSO (1 mL) and 3 h stirring at 110 °C. b The yields are based on isolated products. c Excess indole was used (2.2 mmol) with respect to aryl-iodides. An efficient 2-(2-Pyridyl)imidazole based copper catalyst for N-Arylation of N-heterocycles Gayetri Sarkar Conceptualization Formal analysis Methodology Investigation a Nilaj Bandopadhyay Formal analysis Methodology Investigation a Krishnendu Paramanik Formal analysis Methodology Investigation a Subhajit Saha Formal analysis Methodology Investigation a Subhra Jyoti Panda Formal analysis Validation b Chandra Shekhar Purohit Formal analysis Validation b Bhaskar Biswas Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Hari Sankar Das Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of North Bengal, Darjeeling, 734013, India Department of Chemistry University of North Bengal Darjeeling , 734013 India aDepartment of Chemistry, University of North Bengal, Darjeeling, 734013, India b School of Chemical Sciences, National Institute of Science Education and Research, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, 751005, India School of Chemical Sciences National Institute of Science Education and Research Bhubaneswar Orissa 751005 India bSchool of Chemical Sciences, National Institute of Science Education and Research, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, 751005, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. An earth-abundant copper based 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (L) complex of the type [CuL 2(NO3)](NO3), (1) has been characterized spectroscopically, structurally and electrochemically. The copper(II) in 1 is present in a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal coordination environment and has structural similarity with the well-known 1,10-phenanthroline (L′) coordinated copper catalytic system used in Ullmann-type N-arylation reactions. Complex 1 is more electronically rich than the corresponding 1,10-phenanthroline-based complex, [CuL′ 2(NO3)](NO3), (2) and shows excellent catalytic activity towards N-arylation of nitrogen heterocycles like pyrazole, imidazole, benzimidazole and less reactive indole with aryl-iodides and -bromides. Electronically deficient aryl-chlorides are also successful as a coupling agent for N-arylation with good yields. Wide spectrums of common organic functional groups are also tolerated in our catalytic conditions. A possible mechanistic route for this N-arylation reaction has been proposed by considering several experimental and spectroscopic results along with computational details. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Aryl halides Copper catalyst 2-(2′-Pyridyl)-Imidazole Cross-Coupling Reactions Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction N-arylation is a cornerstone in the synthesis of numerous products including organic building blocks, pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals [1–4]. The most common classical routes for N-arylation are the copper-mediated Ullmann‒Goldberg-type and Chan‒Lam-type reactions (Scheme 1 ) [5–8]. However, the reaction parameter like high temperature (>200 °C), use of the stoichiometric amount of copper salts, moderate yields and long reaction times limit to the overall efficiency for the effective transformations [9]. To overcome these limitations, immense progress were made by Taillefer [10,11], Buchwald [12,13], Ma [14], Goodbrand [15], and many groups [3,4,16-18] with the introduction of bidentate ancillary ligands for the copper ion leading to efficient and mild catalytic systems for N-arylation reactions. From experimental works, CuI, CuII and even Cu° complexes with bidentate ligands can perform the N-arylation [4,12-24]. However, mechanistic investigation suggests that CuI species are the active catalyst involved in the catalytic cycles, therefore, in the case of CuII or Cu° catalysed N-arylation, an initial redox reaction is involved for the generation of active CuI species by in situ chemical reduction or oxidation respectively [25]. In the literature, the combination of Cu-salt and pyridine-based bidentate chelants or their derivatives (Fig. 1 a) as the catalysts is found efficient system used for the synthesis of N-arylated products [3,15,20,26,27]. In comparison to pyridine moiety, the imidazole moiety has more σ-donating ability than its π-accepting properties [28,29] which may stabilize the unstable higher oxidation copper(III) key intermediate state formed during the process of oxidative addition in copper catalysed N-arylation reactions. Therefore, we have chosen N,N-donor type 2-(2′-pyridyl)-imidazole ligand (L) having pyridine moiety as well as imidazole moiety as an auxiliary ligand for copper-mediated N-arylation reaction. On the other hand, nitrate is a labile ligand exhibits both monodentate and bidentate coordination modes expected to have interesting structural property and profound catalytic activity [30]. Herein, we report the spectroscopic and structural characterization of the L-based copper complex (Fig. 1b), [CuL 2(NO3)](NO3) (1) and used as a catalyst for the N-arylation reaction of different N-heterocycles. The complex exhibits excellent catalytic activity towards N-arylation of pyrazole, imidazole, benzimidazole and even less reactive indole[31,32] with different coupling partners including aryl-iodides, -bromides and chemically inert-chlorides[33] at mild conditions. In addition, the generation of active CuI species from pre-catalyst 1 and the mechanistic cycle of this N-arylation reaction has been explored on the basis of electrochemical results, spectroscopic (UV-Vis, 1H NMR, EPR) studies, DFT and some experimental methods. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods The metal salt Cu(NO3)2.3H2O was purchased from SRL, India. The reagents 2-pyridine-carbaxaldehyde and imidazole were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, India; glyoxal, pyrazole, benzimidazole, 2-Methyl indole from TCI, India; indole from SRL, India and 3,5-dimethyl pyrazole and 1,10-phenanthroline from Spectrochem, India. All the other chemicals and solvents were of analytical grade and purchased from commercial suppliers. All the chemicals and solvents were used as received. The ligand 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (L) was prepared using literature procedure (Figure S1-S3, supporting information) [34]. The C, H, N analyses were measured on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN micro analyser (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, USA). 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Advance 400 MHz spectrometer (Bruker, Massachusetts, USA). The infra-red spectra of the complexes were measured on a FTIR-8400S SHIMADZU spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) with KBr pellets. Electronic absorption spectra were recorded with a Hitachi U2910 spectrometer (Hitachi, Japan). Electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were measured on a Q-tof-micro quadruple mass spectrometer. A Gouy balance (Johnson Matthey balance, Model-Mkic) was used to determine the magnetic moment of the complex 1, employing Hg(II) tetrathiocyanatocobaltate(II) as a calibrant. EPR spectroscopic measurements were performed on a Magnettech GmbH EPR Spectrometer MiniScope MS400. Cyclic voltammetry was carried out in 0.1 M tetrabutyl ammonium perchlorate solutions using a three-electrode configuration (glassy-carbon working electrode, Pt counter electrode, Ag/AgCl wire as the reference electrode) and a K-Lyte 1.2 potentiostat system. 2.2 Synthesis of complex [CuL2(NO3)](NO3), (1) The complex 1 was prepared according to the literature procedure by the reaction of two equivalent ligand 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (L) with one equivalent metal precursor Cu(NO3)2.3H2O in ethanol [35]. Elemental analysis calc. (%) for crystalline compound C16H16CuN8O7: C 38.75, H 3.25, N 22.60; found: C 38.62, H 3.08, N 22.37; ESI-MS: (m/z): calc. for: C16H14CuN7O3 415.0454 [1- NO3 −]+ and C16H13CuN6 352.0497 [1 - 2NO3 − - H+]+; found: 415.0496 and 352.0553 (Figure S4). IR (KBr, cm–1; Figure S5): 3436, 1611, 1574. UV-Vis (λmax, nm; Figure S6): 690. 2.3 Synthesis of complex [CuL′2(NO3)](NO3), (2) The complex 2 was also prepared according to the literature procedure by the reaction of two equivalent ligand 1,10-phenanthroline (L′) with one equivalent metal precursor Cu(NO3)2.3H2O in ethanol [36]. Elemental analysis calc. (%) for crystalline compound C24H16CuN6O6.H2O: C 50.93, H 3.21, N 14.85; found: C 50.71, H 3.36, N 14.59; ESI-MS: (m/z): calc. for: C24H16CuN5O3 485.0549 [2 - NO3]+; found: 485.0583 (Figure S7). IR (KBr, cm–1; Figure S8): 3450, 1620, 1511. UV-Vis (λmax, nm; Figure S9): 740. 2.4 General Procedure for 1-catalysed N-arylation reaction In a pressure tube the complex 1 (5 mol %), KOH (84 mg, 1.5 mmol) and DMSO (1 mL) were added followed by substrate amine (1 mmol) and aryl halide (1.5 mmol). After that the reaction vessel was placed to 110 °C in a preheated oil bath with continuous stirring for 3 h. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool down to room temperature. Then 2 mL distilled water was added to the reaction mixture and the N-arylated product was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 x 5 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. After filtration, the crude product was obtained by removal of solvent under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography in silica using hexane/ethyl acetate or hexane/DCM as eluent. 3 Results and discussion The complex 1 is highly soluble in water and common polar solvents. The structural composition of 1 was established by elemental analysis, mass (Figure S4), IR (Figure S5), UV-Vis spectroscopy (Figure S6) and X-ray crystallography. Structural analysis of a suitable single crystal of 1 obtained from slow evaporation of ethanolic solution revealed that this complex crystallized in a triclinic system with P-1 space group (Table S1). An ORTEP representation of complex cation in 1 is shown in Fig. 2 a with the disorder of coordinated nitrate anion. The Cu(II) centric bond distances and angles are given in Table S2 and S3 respectively. Selected interbond and torsion angles are listed in Table S4. The Cu(II) centre in 1 is co-ordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms, two pyridine nitrogen atoms and an oxygen atom of nitrate anion. The N1-Cu1-N4 moiety is nearly linear (bond angle 178.21°) and presents along the axis of a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry, in which the equatorial positions are occupied by two pyridine nitrogen atoms (N3 and N6) and an oxygen atom (O1) of nitrate anion with N3-Cu1-N6 angle of 133.34(9)°, O1-Cu1-N3 angle of 128.82(8)° and O1-Cu1-N6 angle of 97.84(8)°. To calculate the amount of distortion from the ideal geometry, Addison et al. introduced an index parameter tau (τ), where τ = (β – α)/60 [37]. For ideal trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal structures, τ = 1 and 0 respectively, whereas in the present structure, τ = 0.75 (Fig. 2b) close to trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The role of Cu-coordinated nitrate and counterionic nitrate is entirely different as evident from the formation of supramolecular framework in the crystalline phase. The Cu-coordinated nitrate-O interacts strongly with the hydrogen of pyridine and imidazole rings of the ligand forming the nitrate-mediated dimeric Cu(II) complex. While, the dimeric unit interacts with another unit of dimer through a short-distant π∙∙∙π interaction (3.5 Å) between imidazole moiety with adjacent pyridine moiety leading to a 1D polymeric framework. On the contrary, the counterionic nitrate binds two polymeric chains through intermolecular N–H∙∙∙O-water, N–H∙∙∙O-nitrate and O–H∙∙∙O-nitrate hydrogen bonding developing a 3D supramolecular architecture in 1 (Fig. 3 ). The EPR spectrum of 1 shows anisotropic signals with g ǁ = 2.3971 and g ┴ = 2.1564 (Fig. 4 a) indicating the oxidation state of copper is +2 that has a spin of S = 1/2 with a magnetic moment of 1.78 µB. To understand the further electronic configuration of 1, a spin density calculation was performed by DFT (B3LYP method). The spin density calculation also reveals CuII centre spin localization (Fig. 4b). The calculated frontier orbital LUMO of 1 is also located mainly on the CuII centre (Fig. 4d). As the reduction means the addition of an electron to the LUMO of the orbitals, therefore in the case of 1, the observed quasireversible reduction at -0.19 V in DMSO/1M TBAP (Fig. 4c) is a CuII centered redox process. In addition, complex 1 is reduced relatively higher potential (more than 80 mV) than 2 (Fig. 4c) indicating complex 1 is more electronically rich than 2. Therefore, it is expected that the one-electron reduced species of 1 will be more reactive compared to 2. The coordinatively unsaturated redox-active copper(II) complex 1 has structural similarity with the well-known phenanthroline-based copper catalyst used in N-arylation [38]. Based on this information, we directly tested the catalytic activity of 1 (5 mol%) for N-arylation using model substrates pyrazole and iodobenzene at 110 °C in presence of KOH in DMSO (Table 1 , entry 1). Delightfully, complex 1 catalyses the N-arylation reaction successfully with excellent yield. Further, when the same N-arylation was carried out without 1 or using 5 mol% metal salt Cu(NO3)2 or free ligand L, the desired product was not produced effectively (Table 1, entries 2-4) which ensures the advantageous role of catalyst 1 over the metal salt and ligand. Next, the alteration of the reaction parameters does not (Table 1, entries 4-15) improve the catalytic effectiveness of 1. Under the optimized reaction condition (Table 1, entry 1), we further explored the N-arylation of various N-heterocycles with aryl-halides bearing different functional groups in good to excellent yields (70-94%, Table 2 ). N-arylation of pyrazole with substituted aryl-iodides, aryl-bromides and electronically deficient aryl-chlorides (3a-k) were performed successfully with 71-94% yields. Similarly, these aryl-halides were also used successfully in the N-arylation of imidazole (4a-g) benzimidazole (5a-c) and less reactive indole [31,32] (6a-e) with good to excellent yields. Our results demonstrate that the common functional groups such as –NO2, –CN, –COR, –F, –Cl are tolerated in our catalytic condition. In addition, our catalytic method has been observed to be applicable for the gram-scale synthesis of N-arylated products resulting in ∼87% yield for 3a (Scheme S1). After the success of 1 catalysed N-arylation reaction, we became interested in looking into the reaction mechanism. The mechanism of N-arylation using a phenanthroline-based CuI system via oxidative addition, then transmetallation followed by reductive elimination is well established [25,27,33,39-42]. As our native system is CuII, therefore we have checked first the reduction of paramagnetic CuII species (1) into reactive CuI species (1a) in the present catalytic medium. The formation of diamagnetic species 1a was confirmed by silent EPR spectra of the reaction mixture containing 1, DMSO and KOH heated at 110 °C for 15 minutes (Fig. 5 a) against an anisotropic characteristic signal for native d9-CuII species 1 (Fig. 4a). On heating the mixture of 1, KOH and DMSO-d6 for 15 minutes, the shifting of paramagnetic 1H-NMR signals to diamagnetic 1H-NMR signals takes place (Fig. 5b), giving a clear indication of the initial reduction of CuII to CuI in the catalytic medium. The in-situ CuII to CuI conversion in the present system can be well established using optical spectroscopy also (Fig. 5c). Complex 1 shows d9 CuII based d-d transition at around 690 nm. When the spectrum was recorded after heating the mixture (1 and KOH in DMSO) at 110 °C for 15 minutes, the 690 nm band become almost vanished, indicating the conversion to d10 CuI species 1a. These observations are in good agreement with the earlier CuII to CuI transformation in 1,10-phenanthroline coordinated CuII system 2 associated with catalytic cross-coupling reactions [25]. Here, in presence of the base, the solvent DMSO undergoes thermal decomposition to dimethyl sulfide (DMS) which attributes the reduction of CuII to CuI centre, the active species involved in the key step oxidative addition and reductive elimination reactions in C–N coupling [43–45]. The thermal decomposition of DMSO to reducing agent DMS was ensured by the appearance of signals at δ = 2.01 ppm in 1H NMR (Fig. 5b) [46]. As the native complex 1 is a CuII species, therefore we have also checked whether the N-arylation takes place through a radical pathway or a non-radical pathway. The possibility of a radical pathway was excluded by observing that the radical scavenger TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl) could not shut down the reaction completely (Scheme S2). All these mechanistic investigations suggest that our N-arylation reaction follows a nonradical pathway and our native CuII-species 1 converts into CuI-species 1a before entering to the catalytic cycle. Based on this information and along with DFT calculation (Fig. 6 ) and literature support, we propose a possible mechanistic cycle depicted in Scheme 2 . At first, oxidative addition of aryl-halide (Ar–X, X = I, Br, Cl) on in situ generated CuI species 1a proceeds via TS-1 with a calculated activation energy barrier of 44 kcal mol−1 (Fig. 6) to give the CuIII intermediate 1b. Then the N-heterocycle is binding with the CuIII centre of 1b via the substitution reaction (1c) followed by deprotonation resulting in the formation of CuIII species 1d along with the elimination of KX and H2O. The possibility of deprotonation first followed by substitution can be excluded by the observed reactivity of weak acidic indole moiety (pKa of indole N–H in DMSO is 21) in our catalytic condition. On binding with the CuIII centre, the acidity of the indole moiety is increased and then easily gets deprotonated by KOH. Otherwise, very strong bases such as NaH or n-BuLi and water-free conditions will be required to deprotonate it. Next, the reductive elimination of 1d leads to the formation of desired N-arylated products and regeneration of active CuI catalyst 1a. The calculated energy barrier (Fig. 6) and energy profile of the reaction path correlates the reported values to a great extent [47–50]. 4 Conclusion Using the π-acidic chelating 2-(2′-pyridyl)-imidazole ligand, we have reported here a CuII complex, 1 with distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. In the crystal structure, π∙∙∙π interactions and hydrogen bonding lead to an interesting supramolecular polymeric framework. The CuII centre in 1 reduces at a relatively higher potential corresponding to 1,10-phenanthroline-based complex 2. Finally, the redox active complex 1 was used as a catalyst for the N-arylation of N-heterocycles including pyrazole, imidazole, benzimidazole and less reactive indole using different aryl-halides (Ar-X, X= I, Br, Cl) as a coupling partner. The cross-coupled N-arylated products were isolated in good to excellent yields. Spectroscopic studies (EPR, NMR, UV-Vis) and DFT calculations show the reduction of CuII-complex 1 to CuI-complex 1a during the initiation of the catalytic cycle following the conventional mechanistic path for the coupling process. This newly approached methodology would be an efficient synthetic strategy to produce N-arylated products under an ambient condition and may stand as a suitable alternative method for N-arylation employing the phenanthroline-based-Cu-catalyst. Supplementary data CCDC 2244598 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Characterization data of ligand and metal complexes, structural parameters including bond distances and angles, gram-scale synthesis of N-arylated product, 1H & 13C NMR spectra of N-arylated products, mechanistic details, theoretical calculations etc. are given here. coredata.dc:description: An earth-abundant copper based 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (L) complex of the type [CuL 2(NO3)](NO3), (1) has been characterized spectroscopically, structurally and electrochemically. The copper(II) in 1 is present in a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal coordination environment and has structural similarity with the well-known 1,10-phenanthroline (L′) coordinated copper catalytic system used in Ullmann-type N-arylation reactions. Complex 1 is more electronically rich than the corresponding 1,10-phenanthroline-based complex, [CuL′ 2(NO3)](NO3), (2) and shows excellent catalytic activity towards N-arylation of nitrogen heterocycles like pyrazole, imidazole, benzimidazole and less reactive indole with aryl-iodides and -bromides. Electronically deficient aryl-chlorides are also successful as a coupling agent for N-arylation with good yields. Wide spectrums of common organic functional groups are also tolerated in our catalytic conditions. A possible mechanistic route for this N-arylation reaction has been proposed by considering several experimental and spectroscopic results along with computational details.
coredata.dc:title: An efficient 2-(2-Pyridyl)imidazole based copper catalyst for N-Arylation of N-heterocycles
